title: 105_hr3032
content: The Act titled "Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998" and outlines additional responsibilities for the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers. This includes implementing statutes like the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers. Proposed revisions to the Government-wide Federal Acquisition Regulation must be published within 120 days of enactment, with final regulations to be effective within 30 days of publication. Additionally, related amendments to the Miller Act are included. The Miller Act is amended to improve payment bond protection by equalizing the amount of the payment bond to the performance bond. It also extends payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers, ensuring timely payment for progress payments and labor/material costs. The Miller Act is amended to enhance payment bond protection for subcontractors and suppliers by clarifying language and preserving their rights. The Miller Act is amended to modernize service of payment bond claims and eliminate delays in payment bond protection. The Miller Act is amended to allow suits to be filed within 90 days after the last labor or material was furnished, even if the contractor denies payment. Additionally, courts may award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party in frivolous suits under the Act. The Miller Act is amended to allow suits within 90 days after the last labor or material was furnished. Courts may award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest in frivolous suits under the Act. Interest awarded is calculated from the claim date to payment using applicable interest rates. Accountability of Contracting Officers is emphasized in the Act. Contracting officers are responsible for obtaining and maintaining payment bonds for contracts. If a court finds that a required payment bond is not in effect due to the officer's negligence, the person bringing the suit may petition to sue the United States for the owed amount.
